common_symptoms.name: Lower Back Pain

common_causes.mechanism: Hip flexor tightness + weak glutes = anterior pelvic tilt and lumbar compression
Spine compensates for lack of trunk control, leading to overuse
Herniation, bulging, or degeneration causing nerve compression

red_flags: Numbness or tingling down the legs
Loss of bowel/bladder control (cauda equina syndrome - ER immediately)
Severe night pain that wakes you up
Unexplained weight loss with back pain

immediate: Avoid sitting for extended periods - take standing/walking breaks every 30-45 min
Gentle movement is better than complete rest (unless acute injury)
Ice for acute pain (<48hrs), heat for chronic tightness
movement_suggestions: Dead bug or bird dog exercises for core stability
Hip flexor stretches (couch stretch, kneeling hip flexor)

common_symptoms.response_template:
Lower back pain is brutal, especially for desk workers. Most common culprit: tight hip flexors and weak glutes from sitting all day creating anterior pelvic tilt - basically your pelvis rotates forward and compresses your lumbar spine.

**What actually helps:**
- Break up sitting time (every 30-45min)
- Hip flexor stretches (couch stretch is ðŸ”¥)
- Glute activation (bridges, clamshells)
- Core stability work (dead bugs, not crunches)

**Red flags - see a doc if:**
- Numbness/tingling down your legs
- Weakness in legs
- Pain after an injury/fall
- Not improving after 4-6 weeks

common_symptoms.name: Shoulder Pain

common_causes.mechanism: Rounded shoulders + forward head posture = chronic internal rotation, anterior shoulder tightness
Overuse or weakness in stabilizing muscles
Subacromial space narrowing, pinching tendons during overhead movements
common_causes.prevalence: Common, often from poor scapular control

immediate: Assess your desk ergonomics - mouse too far forward?
Check monitor height (top of screen at eye level)
movement_suggestions: External rotation exercises (banded or light weight)
when_to_see_professional: Significant loss of range of motion
Pain with specific movements that doesn't improve

common_symptoms.response_template:
Shoulder pain from desk work usually isn't the shoulder itself - it's a posture problem. Rounded shoulders + forward head = your shoulder lives in internal rotation all day, which cranks up tension in the anterior shoulder and can lead to impingement.

**What actually helps:**
- Fix desk ergonomics (monitor height, mouse position)
- External rotation work (banded exercises)
- Open up the chest (doorway stretches)
- Strengthen posterior shoulder (face pulls)
- Scapular control (wall angels)

**Red flags - see a doc if:**
- Severe pain after injury
- Can't move arm at all
- Night pain preventing sleep
- No improvement after 4-6 weeks

common_symptoms.name: Wrist / Carpal Tunnel Pain

common_causes.mechanism: Constant typing with extended wrists compresses median nerve in carpal tunnel
Wrist deviation, poor forearm support, awkward angles
Lack of stability requires more tension, leading to overuse

red_flags: Muscle wasting in the thumb (thenar atrophy)

immediate: Check keyboard/mouse position - wrists should be neutral, not extended
Use wrist rest or adjust desk height
Shake out hands and wrists regularly
movement_suggestions: Forearm strengthening (wrist curls, reverse wrist curls)
Grip strength work (stress ball, hand grippers)
when_to_see_professional: Symptoms not improving with ergonomic changes

common_symptoms.response_template:
Wrist pain from typing is usually carpal tunnel or tendonitis from repetitive wrist extension. Your hand has 27 bones and 34 muscles controlling it - that's a lot of complexity that doesn't like doing the exact same motion 10,000 times a day.

**What actually helps:**
- Fix ergonomics FIRST (neutral wrist position, keyboard height)
- Take micro-breaks (20-30 min intervals)
- Nerve glides (median nerve flossing)
- Strengthen forearms (not just stretch)
- Shake out hands regularly

**Red flags - see a doc if:**
- Numbness that doesn't go away
- Muscle wasting in thumb area
- Dropping things frequently
- Night pain waking you up

common_symptoms.name: Neck / Tech Neck Pain

common_causes.mechanism: For every inch forward, adds ~10 lbs of force on neck. Looking down at phone/laptop creates massive lever stress
Looking down all day keeps neck flexed, overworks posterior neck muscles
Superficial muscles compensate, creating tension and trigger points

immediate: Raise monitor height (top of screen at eye level)
Check phone usage - avoid prolonged looking down
movement_suggestions: Chin tucks for deep neck flexor strength
Thoracic spine mobility (cat-cow, thread the needle)
when_to_see_professional: Pain radiating into arms with numbness/tingling

common_symptoms.response_template:
Tech neck is physics being brutal: for every inch your head moves forward, you add ~10 pounds of force on your neck muscles. Looking down at your phone at 60Â° can put 60 POUNDS of stress on your cervical spine. Your head weighs 10-12 lbs but leverage multiplies everything.

**What actually helps:**
- Raise monitor to eye level (top of screen)
- Limit phone looking-down time
- Chin tucks (strengthen deep neck flexors)
- Thoracic mobility (your upper back affects your neck)
- Upper trap + levator scapulae stretches

**Red flags - see a doc if:**
- Numbness/tingling down arms
- Severe headaches with vision changes
- Pain after whiplash/injury
- No improvement after 4 weeks
